ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Figured bass realization, basic jazz techniques and reading lead sheets, basic music theory especially in relation to both baroque/classical figured bass and jazz
Gain knowledge of chord progressions, chord notation for both figured bass and jazz, how to harmonize different pieces, and expanded knowledge of scales.
How to read jazz lead sheets and play through figured bass exercises. Common chord progressions and suspensions.
I learned a lot about jazz theory and improved my skills at realizing figured bass. I found the combination of jazz and baroque music very interesting, and I feel I improved in my musicianship.
Figured bass realization and jazz lead sheet comping.
So much! Chord voicings, functions, common progressions. Figured bass, which was a whole realm of music and notation that I knew nothing about.
I learned more about the keyboard and different improv , jazz , and inversions.
Became a better piano player, learned common chord progressions and an introduction to figured bass.
Cord progressions, theory about the keyboard and how to harmonize.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Very reasonable grading system and open to taking it at your own pace

can feel slow at times depending on your music background. Also could feel too difficult given your music background
(Optional) lectures were irrelevant and disorganized. Regular daily practice is helpful.

The fact that it is all practice-based is really really nice. I do think that there are certain things we learned in class such as the function of chords or how to construct them (rather than just applying them exactly as written in the exercises) that could have been reinforced more since we didn't need to think about them for most of our practice. I liked that toward the end of the semester there was more of a focus on building the chords with the proper voicings and extensions and not just relying on applying the jazz drills verbatim.
Also, during the first few weeks of class because of shopping period we had lecture prior to the start of that weeks practice on Monday. I found it much easier to practice during those weeks because once we were in a groove of lecture on Monday at 5pm, I found it hard to actually practice Monday evening (and hard to practice prior to lecture) so I would have to fit a practice day into the weekend which was just logistically difficult sometimes and also gave me less time to practice and look at the material before office hours on Wednesday. I wonder if it would work to have lecture on Wednesday and office hours on Monday- just a thought.
It could be a little more structured and involved. It could be a bit more differentiated each week. I really loved the jazz exercises and repetitive practice.
Not much to say, the structure of the class was pretty straightforward and did a fine job helping me achieve my goal of getting better at piano.

I enjoyed the practicing aspect but the lecture could have been more engaging and it would have been nice to play/listen to more music together. Office hours were incredibly helpful as it was nice to see the keys.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I think this is a chill course to take to focus on your keyboard skills, brush up on some music theory, and learn a bit about figured bass and jazz. Overall an interesting course to take and I enjoyed it!

Yes. This is an easier humanities credit for those who already have basic knowledge of piano and can commit to daily practices throughout the week. I really learned a lot about chords (which I did not fully understand before) even though I didn't engage that much with the course.
I would recommend this course to students interested in developing their harmonic skills as well as those who want to learn more about jazz specifically.

Take this course if you need a theory credit for lessons or if you want to practice your figured bass/jazz skills daily. This is a skills class, not a content-learning class, so take it if that's what you're looking for.

Absolutely. No matter your experience with music/piano there is a lot to be learned unless you are already very well-versed in both jazz and classical. Either way, the course is very accessible to all skill levels!
If you already know how to play, it is a good way to keep you accountable and to learn a bit more ways to arrange/do patterns.
Yes, for a fifth class to someone wanting to learn piano.
Yes! I learned a lot of theory and the regular practice routine really helped me improve.
